column4: yeah, its not particularly difficult to do that.  are you trying to do this: http://www.dd-wrt.com/wiki/index.php/Image:Standard_bridge_large.jpg ? if so, you shouldn't need hostap
Randy_ that's exactly what I'm trying to do

I'm connecting my laptop to my wireless router as normal, then I'm using the ethernet port on the laptop to share the connection to a computer, and that works fine.  I also want to share to a second computer though, and when I hook the shared ethernet connection from the laptop into a switch, both clients won't work
no big deal.  did you assign IP addresses manually?
are you doing connection sharing through something like firestarter?

I tried that, the connection sharing in ubuntu creates a new 10. network while my router's network is 192., so I assigned manual 10. to both the clients I was trying to connect to the switch but they still wouldn't work at the same time
I'm just doing sharing through NetworkManager
yeah, connection sharing doesn't quite work right in Network Manager... reluctantly.  ok. let me guess, you assigned 192.168.(something).10 to *both* computers
no.  I mean the connection sharing creates a 10.x.x.x network and no I didn't give them both the same address :p
ok ok, you understand of course why i would ask ;) just taking care of the easy stuff first ;)

now, the way i would do it is much simpler than dealing with NetworkManager, even though it *seems* more difficult at first.  we can install and verify, rather quickly, through the command line, whether or not this works, which of course it will.  there are only a few steps to this.
sure I'm willing to give anything a shot

step 1) wireless connectivity (the bridge).  step 2) turn on routing (hella important) step 3) assign a network to the ethernet port.  step 4) assign IP's from that network to devices on the switch plugged into the ethernet port)

there are (2) ways we can do this, depending on which one you would prefer.  would you like to (a) extend your network so that you don't have a sub-subnet for the switch or (b) would you like a true wireless bridge that allows DHCP to reach the connection-shared devices?
wait, that was the same option worded differently.  the other option is a sub-subnet like you've been trying to do up to this point
whichever is easier, I can manually assign the addresses easily enough if necessary.  I don't need them on a different subnet than the main internal network
you should probably pm me, so we can go through this ;)
